private_information: I am responsible for the moves: 1. unstack(G,B), 2. putdown(G), 3. pickup(G), 4. stack(G,F), 9. unstack(G,F), 10. stack(G,B)
I can move only the top block of a stack and carry only one block at a time
mover1.goal: Execute my assigned block moves and report my local state after performing them.

private_information: I am responsible for the moves: 5. pickup(B), 6. stack(B,G), 7. unstack(B,G), 8. stack(B,A)
I can move only the top block of a stack and carry only one block at a time
mover2.goal: Execute my assigned block moves and report my local state after performing them.

private_information: I will integrate the local reports from the movers and produce a final PDDL domain and problem suitable for the FastDownwards planner
orchestrator.goal: Integrate agent reports, derive the final blocks arrangement after the executed action sequence, and emit a PDDL domain and problem encoding the initial state and final goal for FastDownwards.

public_information: Blocks world rules: only the top block of a stack can be moved and only one block can be carried at a time.
Blocks involved: A B C D E F G.
Initial arrangement: A on E, B on table, C on D, D on table, E on C, F on table, G on B.
Sequence of executed actions in order: unstack(G,B), putdown(G), pickup(G), stack(G,F), pickup(B), stack(B,G), unstack(B,G), stack(B,A), unstack(G,F), stack(G,B).

local_state.system_prompt: You are mover1. Using your private information and the public blocks world facts, simulate the assigned moves in order and produce a concise local state representation listing each block and what it is resting on after your moves. Use the format: Block:A on:X or Block:B on_table. Do not emit PDDL. Do not assume information you do not have.
local_state.prompt: Initial arrangement and public facts are provided by the environment. Apply moves 1,2,3,4,9,10 as listed in your private information to compute the local arrangement for all blocks under your view. Output the local arrangement in the single-line structured format described in the system_prompt.

local_state.system_prompt: You are mover2. Using your private information and the public blocks world facts, simulate the assigned moves in order and produce a concise local state representation listing each block and what it is resting on after your moves. Use the format: Block:A on:X or Block:B on_table. Do not emit PDDL. Do not assume information you do not have.
local_state.prompt: Initial arrangement and public facts are provided by the environment. Apply moves 5,6,7,8 as listed in your private information to compute the local arrangement for all blocks under your view. Output the local arrangement in the single-line structured format described in the system_prompt.

pddl.system_prompt: You are the orchestrator and an expert in PDDL for FastDownwards. Integrate the local state reports from mover1 and mover2 and derive the final arrangement of all blocks after the full action sequence. Produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem encoded for FastDownwards. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Keep agent actions distinct if representing them, but the primary goal is to encode the initial state and the final arrangement as the goal for FastDownwards.
pddl.prompt: Public information: Blocks world rules and the initial arrangement are provided by the environment. You will receive two local state reports: {state_mover1} and {state_mover2}. Integrate these reports to determine the final arrangement of all blocks after the executed sequence: unstack(G,B), putdown(G), pickup(G), stack(G,F), pickup(B), stack(B,G), unstack(B,G), stack(B,A), unstack(G,F), stack(G,B). Produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem suitable for FastDownwards such that the problem initial state corresponds to the original initial arrangement and the problem goal corresponds to the derived final arrangement. Enclose the domain in <domain></domain> and the problem in <problem></problem>. Do not include extraneous commentary.
